FBI verbosely recommends no charges. Attorney General Loretta Lynch has said she would follow the recommendations of the FBI and career prosecutors.
http://www.wsj.com/articles/fbi-won-t-recommend-clinton-be-indicted-over-private-email-use-1467731774 "In our system, the prosecutors make the decisions about whether charges are appropriate based on evidence the FBI has helped collect. Although we don’t normally make public our recommendations to the prosecutors, we frequently make recommendations and engage in productive conversations with prosecutors about what resolution may be appropriate, given the evidence. In this case, given the importance of the matter, I think unusual transparency is in order. Although there is evidence of potential violations of the statutes regarding the handling of classified information, our judgment is that no reasonable prosecutor would bring such a case. Prosecutors necessarily weigh a number of factors before bringing charges. There are obvious considerations, like the strength of the evidence, especially regarding intent. Responsible decisions also consider the context of a person’s actions, and how similar situations have been handled in the past. In looking back at our investigations into mishandling or removal of classified information, we cannot find a case that would support bringing criminal charges on these facts. All the cases prosecuted involved some combination of: clearly intentional and willful mishandling of classified information; or vast quantities of materials exposed in such a way as to support an inference of intentional misconduct; or indications of disloyalty to the United States; or efforts to obstruct justice. We do not see those things here. To be clear, this is not to suggest that in similar circumstances, a person who engaged in this activity would face no consequences. To the contrary, those individuals are often subject to security or administrative sanctions. But that is not what we are deciding now. As a result, although the Department of Justice makes final decisions on matters like this, we are expressing to Justice our view that no charges are appropriate in this case."

Attorney General Accepts Recommendation Not to Charge Hillary Clinton
http://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/07/us/politics/hillary-clinton-loretta-lynch.htm WASHINGTON — The investigation into Hillary Clinton’s email server is over, Attorney General Loretta E. Lynch said on Wednesday. In a brief written statement, she said she accepted the F.B.I.’s recommendation that no one be charged in the case, which has engulfed Mrs. Clinton’s presidential ambitions for more than a year. “I received and accepted their unanimous recommendation that the thorough, year-long investigation be closed and that no charges be brought against any individuals within the scope of the investigation,” Mrs. Lynch said. The attorney general said she met with James B. Comey, the director of the F.B.I., and other prosecutors and agents on Wednesday afternoon before closing the case. Ms. Lynch had promised to accept the F.B.I. recommendations after creating a political furor by meeting on her airplane last week for 30 minutes with former President Bill Clinton. The announcement by Mrs. Lynch came on the eve of a congressional hearing Thursday morning at which Mr. Comey is scheduled to testify about the email investigation and the decision not to pursue charges. Mr. Comey announced his recommendation on Tuesday despite finding that Mrs. Clinton and her top aides were “extremely careless” in their distribution of classified information across unsecured email networks. The apparent contradiction in Mr. Comey’s recommendation is expected to be the focus of sharp, bipartisan questioning at the hearing. But it is unclear whether Mr. Comey will be willing to provide any additional details about the investigation or the process investigators used to reach their conclusions. For Mrs. Clinton, the public announcement by the attorney general formally ends a legal cloud that has been shadowing her campaign and comes just weeks before she will accept her party’s nomination to be president. But as the Republicans’ quick decision to hold congressional hearings proves, the political damage from her use of a private email server is most likely not over. That damage was compounded on Tuesday when Mr. Comey said Mrs. Clinton should have known better than to allow such sensitive material to be sent over an unsecured network. Brian Fallon, a spokesman for Mrs. Clinton’s campaign, said on Twitter, “With the AG accepting Director Comey’s recommendation, this case is resolved, no matter Republicans’ attempts to continue playing politics.”

"The investigation into Hillary Clinton’s email server is over, Attorney General Loretta E. Lynch said on Wednesday. After the events of the last few days, I wanted to post some thoughts about what the question means, how it can resolve, and what affect the FBI’s recommendation will have on the outcome.  The question asks whether Hillary Clinton will be indicted. There are multiple ways to get a defendant in front of a judge, but the question narrows those options to one: the indictment.  Neither a deal between Clinton and the government in lieu of an indictment nor the DOJ charging Clinton with a non-indictable offense will resolve the question.  Obviously, Clinton will not be indicted if the FBI investigation fails to uncover evidence of a crime.

Assuming the FBI does recommend an indictable offense, keep in mind that an indictment comes from a grand jury and *only* a grand jury.  The DOJ may accept the FBI’s recommendation but that still does not mean Clinton has been indicted.  The DOJ must take the additional steps of empaneling a grand jury and presenting the evidence of her alleged crimes to them.  The grand jury would then vote to “true bill” (indict) or “no bill” (not indict) on each of the potential crimes presented.  Usually, a grand jury does what the DOJ wants, but that is more of a factor that grand jury proceedings are one-sided and the DOJ determines what to present rather than the grand jury simply rubber stamping the indictment.  One fact we do not know is whether a grand jury has already been empaneled.  If they are already hearing testimony and reviewing evidence, then the process would be further along. Some of the right-leaning media outlets seem to believe one has been empaneled.  I have not found anything concrete to support their claim but the DOJ will not comment or acknowledge ongoing grand jury proceedings. Another consideration is that I can foresee a disagreement between the prosecutors and the FBI about how to proceed and would expect the prosecutors to prevail.  The FBI’s standard will be probable cause, a fairly low threshold.  However, attorneys involved may have a different idea about how to proceed based on a different standard, which is beyond a reasonable doubt. I expect they will want to go forward only if they are satisfied they have enough to convict Clinton.  That is often a factor in pre-trial decisions.  AG Lynch has said she will accept the recommendations of the FBI and the career prosecutors involved with the investigation, but she will probably defer to the prosecutors if a disagreement exists about how to proceed. The primary reason I am so low on this question has nothing to do with whether, ultimately, Clinton will be indicted, although I lean toward no on that (perhaps another post to explain).  I am low because the grand jury process takes a long time, other ways to resolve the case without an indictment exist, and I expect those who make the decisions will give careful consideration to all the available options.

I am updating my previous forecast because I think that the Base rate should be limited to those involved in a scandal.  Between 1945 and the present according to wikipedia 7 cabinet members were involved in scandals.  Of those 42% were convicted (the others weren't indicted).   Following the rationale from my first post I think that the chance of her being indicted is substantially less because it appears that there was nothing to indict her on in the first 30K of emails that she turned over and then it was reported in January 2016 that the FBI was able to recover the deleted ones.  They have had 4 to 5 months to complete that process and review the emails and still no smoking gun so I am reducing the 42% by 75%. Giving a prediction of 10.5%.

Base Rate.  I calculated the base rate by looking at political scandals involving cabinet members (wikipedia) since WWII.  I made some assumptions to make the calculations easier.  There were 14 presidential terms.  In each term there were 12 (under Truman) to 16 (under obama) cabinet members. During this time 7 cabinet ministers were involved in scandals and 3 were convicted of crimes.  So I calculated my base rate as 3 convictions/14 cabinet members*14 terms= 1.5% Then I considered the specific information that I could find.  1)	Clinton exclusively used her family's private email server for official communications,
2)	 Charges - violated State Departmentprotocols and procedures, as well as federal laws and regulations governingrecordkeeping. 
3)	From what I could find it seems like there were two main points of contention that Clinton violated FOIA, that known classified information was sent at the time or that information that should have been classified was sent (in violation of the non-disclosure agreement she signed for her security clearance.)
4)	Clinton turned over about 30,000 emails (about half) and said that the other half were personal and deleted.  She turned over her server and news reports say that the FBI was able to recover deleted emails starting in January 2016. None of the emails so far was classified at the time it was sent.
5)	She has not been charged yet.  If there was a FOIA case to be made I think it would have been made with the 30K emails.  Also no material that was classified at the time was sent.  So that leaves the 30K emails that were deleted, I am thinking that since they have had 4-5 months to recover and review the emails that there were no clear violations reducing the chance that she will be indicted.
6)	It seems like the more difficult to tie down part is the non-disclosure agreement signed by Clinton as part of gaining her security clearance, requires that sensitive information – and that this can include information received orally, has to be identified and then marked as classified by the sender (ie Clinton) before she sends it.  There are undoubtedly cases where this classification is clear cut but many cases are not.  If this were clear cut it would have already been settled with the original emails.  Again I interpret this as reducing the chance that she will be indicted.
7) So I don't think there is no chance but I also think it is very unlikely.
What the heck am I doing at 0%?  I must have been temporarily insane.  This could happen!  Not because she committed some egregious violation of the law, but because of politics.

There are multiple layers to answering this question, involving multiple key players and key agencies. First, with the FBI allegedly actively investigating the issue with Clinton's email server, the agency would need to conclude that there was criminal activity and recommend to the DOJ that they indict Clinton. Then, the DOJ (and more specifically the AG) would need to choose to follow the FBI's advice and actually indict Clinton. Given statements by the FBI, DOJ and others, it does not appear that Clinton will be implicated in criminal activity whatsoever before the November election.  However, I am also cautious not to put my estimate at 0% for a couple of reasons. First, I support Clinton which could bias my assessment of whether she ought be indicted, rather than whether she will be. I want to preempt this potential bias by assessing only the facts and realizing a very slight possibility of indictment. Second, Pres. Obama and others have indicated there will be no political maneuvering in the investigation, which at least partially subsides the "political protection" possibility (http://www.politico.com/story/2016/04/barack-obama-hillary-clinton-justice-221770).  Therefore, my estimate is now at 5%. though I expect it may decrease with further developments from the FBI/DOJ investigation.

Opearing on the assumption that a case for indictment would be based on 1) the use of personal email breaking federal law or 2) the distribution of classified info, here's my rationale.  While it's clear she clearly broke procedure, the argument that she broke federal law is weaker. If she is indicted, she could prevail and then she would look like a strong victim, which would help her case. The classified argument doesn't hold up because the docs were classified after they were shared. However, if it could be shown that she did distribute docs that she knew to be classified at the time, then I would expect to see an indictment, which is where the 10% comes in.

Given that the emails in question were not considered classified until after the fact, the case already seems weak to me. While the number of officials using private email servers is low, the number of officials using private email addresses is high, and that speaks to more people misunderstanding the insecure nature of email than anything else. Ironically, Clinton's choice to host her own server could have been seen as an attempt to beef up her email security, not the opposite. The bottom line is the intent question: did Clinton intend to pose security risks with her private email server? I highly doubt it. She made a mistake, and she has admitted to it, but if you are looking for proof of some nefarious intent on her part, I don't think you are going to find it.

"Former FBI agent J.J. Smith was charged with five felonies, including grossly negligent mishandling of classified information for allowing an FBI informant to obtain highly sensitive bureau information. Smith was having an affair with the informant, Katrina Leung, who was also working for Chinese intelligence. Leung wound up with several FBI documents including a “Secret” memo on Chinese fugitives and an unclassified FBI phone directory. She said she regularly took documents from Smith’s briefcase, which he often left open when he visited her. In a plea deal, Smith pleaded guilty to a single felony count of lying to investigators. He was sentenced to three months house arrest, three years probation and a $10,000 fine. " . . .former senior State Department official, Don Keyser, pled guilty in 2005 to felony charges of removing government records as well as lying to investigators and lying on a Customs Declaration. A search found 3,659 classified documents at Keyser’s home: 1,976 of them “Secret” and 28 “Top Secret,” as well as 28 floppy disks containing more “Secret” documents. Keyser’s wife said she alerted him to the presence of the classified materials but he apparently never sought to return them. The removal-of-records charge Keyser admitted to is one some conservative lawyers have urged be leveled at Clinton. It does not require that the documents in question be classified. However, the government’s reason for concern in Keyser’s case went beyond his storage of classified info at home: undercover FBI agents twice observed him in a car having what appeared to be intimate contact with a Taiwanese intelligence agent, Isabelle Cheng. The longtime diplomat also lied about his relationship with Cheng and took classified information on an unreported trip to Taiwan. Keyser was ultimately sentenced to a year and a day in prison and a $25,000 fine. The lead prosecutor on the Keyser case, David Laufman, is now the head of the Justice Department’s counterintelligence section — the office believed to be overseeing the FBI probe into Clinton’s server.   "A Boeing engineer who took home what prosecutors called “an adult giraffe” ’s-worth of sensitive information on missile defense programs, Abraham Lesnik, pled guilty in 2008 to a felony charge of unauthorized retention of classified data.
Lesnik’s travel and ties to Israel appear to have been a factor, but prosecutors said they had no evidence he planned to misuse the roughly 2000 classified documents, including about 400 marked top secret found on a thumb drive, laptop and other devices at his California home and in a storage locker. Lesnik’s lawyer argued vehemently that no criminal charges should have been brought in the case. Prosecutors asked for a four-year prison sentence. A judge gave the scientist three years’ probation. "The toughest punishment handed down in recent memory for mishandling classified information went to former National Security Agency analyst Kenneth Ford Jr., who was sentenced in 2006 to six years in prison for taking to his home two boxes of classified documents and other records from NSA headquarters in Maryland. He was also convicted of lying on a job application form. "A contract linguist working for the Navy in Bahrain, James Hitselberger, was hit with six felony charges after being seen taking classified printouts to his room and cutting the headings off classified records. Hitselberger appears to have fueled investigators’ suspicions by sending some classified records to archives at Stanford University’s Hoover Institution and by disappearing in Europe after being dismissed from his job in the Persian Gulf. In a plea deal, Hitselberger pled guilty to misdemeanor mishandling of classified records. He was sentenced to time served: two months in jail and eight months on house arrest. Some have compared Hitselberger cutting headings off the classified documents to a message Clinton sent to a top aide in June 2011, telling him to work around a broken secure fax machine by editing a classified ‘talking points’ document and sending it over ordinary email. “If they can't, turn into nonpaper [with] no identifying heading and send nonsecure," Clinton wrote. State Department officials have said there’s no evidence the aide, Jake Sullivan, ever sent the talking points via email. Republicans said the episode showed Clinton’s disregard for the security of classified information, but other former officials said the incident was benign and that anonymizing information is a routine way of handling such information in unclassified channels.

This Politico story (http://www.politico.com/story/2016/04/hillary-clinton-prosecution-past-cases-221744) has most of the key information. To begin with, between 2011 and 2015, only 20% of cases referred to federal prosecutors resulted in charges being filed; in every case when charges were filed the defendants pled guilty, strongly suggesting slam-dunk cases. Additionally, between 2002 and 2004 the State Department considered disciplinary action in 170 cases of security violations; none of those cases resulted in prosecution.
